Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of calcined x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. (b) Co 2p XPS spectrum of the calcined x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. (c) Pt 4d XPS spectrum of the calcined x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) H2-TPR profiles of calcined x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. (b) H2-TPD profiles of reduced x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. (c) CO2-TPD profiles of reduced x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst after reduction at 250 °C. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Yields of various products over Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts. 3 MPa, 180 °C, H2/CO2 = 3/1. The error bar was calculated based on three independent measurements. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Correlation between the yield of different products. (a) Y MeOH-Y CH4, (b) Y HA-Y CH4, (c) Y HA-Y MeOH. The error bar was calculated based on three independent measurements. The lines are only for visual guidance. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TOFs of (a) CO2 conversion, (b) methane, (c) methanol, and (d) Higher alcohols formation over x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. The plots are only for visual guidance. contributed equally. CO2 hydrogenation presents a crucial pathway for carbon circularity. The activation, adsorption, and hydrogen spillover are key processes in CO2 hydrogenation. This study investigates the effects of hydrogen spillover induced by Pt on CO2 hydrogenation over Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts. A series of Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation and employed for CO2 hydrogenation. The optimized Pt-promoted Co-Al catalyst efficiently converts CO2, leading to the formation of methane (46.6 mmol gcat −1 h−1), methanol (509.4 μmol gcat −1 h−1), and higher alcohols (220.6 μmol gcat −1 h−1). The Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts facilitate hydrogen spillover, optimizing the catalysts’ reducibility and exposing more active sites. Moreover, the hydrogen adsorption is weakened due to the Pt induced hydrogen spillover, which facilitates the formation of *HCOO, *CH3, and *CO intermediates. This in turn facilitate the coupling between *HCOO/*CO and *CH3, enhancing the formation of higher alcohols. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Hydrogen spillover Platinum Cobalt Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Since the industrial revolution in the early 19th century, emissions of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide (CO2) have steadily increased due to the overuse of fossil fuels. Various strategies have been applied to curb this trend. Amongst, carbon capture and utilization (CCU) technology not only reduces CO2 emissions effectively but also transforms CO2 into valuable chemical products, attracting significant interest [1]. Through CO2 hydrogenation, various products such as alkanes (CnH2n+2), alkenes (CnH2n), carboxylic acids (R-COOH), alcohols (R-OH), and carbon monoxide (CO) can be produced [2–5]. Currently, many catalysts have been developed for CO2 hydrogenation, with Rh, Pd, Ru, Pt, Co, Cu, Ni, Mo, and Fe as active metals [6]. While noble metal based catalysts demonstrate outstanding CO2 hydrogenation activity, their high costs hinder the large-scale application. It is worth noting that non-noble metal Co-based catalysts are versatile for CO2 hydrogenation, resulting in the production of methane, methanol, and higher alcohols, and thus represent promising materials for large-scale application [7–11]. In the CO2 hydrogenation process, active hydrogen atoms play a crucial role in forming key intermediates. Therefore, hydrogen spillover is vital in regulating the activity and selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts [12,13]. The spillover of hydrogen involves a two-step process: initially, hydrogen molecules dissociate into highly reactive hydrogen atoms at the metal sites on the surface. Subsequently, these hydrogen atoms migrate to the support’s surface via metal-support interfaces or through other channels that possess functional capabilities [14]. Pt demonstrates a significant enhancement effect on CO2 hydrogenation, attributed to its strong ability to dissociate hydrogen, which in turn initiates the hydrogen spillover phenomenon [15]. He et al. compared the promotional effects of various noble metals on the hydrogenation of CO2 to alcohols using Co3O4 as the base catalyst [16]. The alcohol yield from the catalysts is ranked as follows: Pt/Co3O4 > Rh/Co3O4 > Ru/Co3O4 > Pd/Co3O4, showcasing the superior promotional influence of Pt on CO2 hydrogenation for Co-based catalysts. Further studies reveal that within Co-Pt catalysts, hydrogen atoms on Pt sites are capable of migrating to Co particles via long-distance hydrogen spillover. This migration aids in the transformation of CoO to Co0 thereby creating additional active sites and enhancing the CO2 hydrogenation performance [17]. Additionally, Pt as a promoter affects the formation of oxygen vacancies. In the case of a Pt/HₓMoO3—y catalyst, which consists of an oxygen-deficient molybdenum sub-oxide catalyst and Pt nanoparticles, the Pt nanoparticles serve dual functions: act as sites for H2 dissociation to replenish oxygen vacancies and as catalytic sites for hydrogenating the CO intermediate, ultimately yielding methanol via CO2 hydrogenation [18]. Herein, the effects of a Pt as promoter and hydrogen spillover on the performance of CO2 hydrogenation over Pt-Co-Al catalysts were investigated. The presence of Pt significantly enhances the reduction of Co-Al catalysts at low temperatures, optimizing the amount of Co0 and Co2+ in the catalysts and providing abundant active sites for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The hydrogen spillover induced by the Pt promoter leads to moderate adsorption of H/CO2, facilitating the formation of *CHx/*CO/*HCOO intermediates and enhancing the coupling between *CHx and *CO/*HCOO. Consequently, a high CO2 conversion rate of 47.35 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and a higher alcohols formation rate of 220.6 μmol gcat −1 h−1 are achieved. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts The Pt-Co-Al hydroxide precursors were synthesized via a co-precipitation method adapted from Ref. [19,20]. First, solution A was prepared by mixing solutions containing 0.108 M Co(NO3)2·6 H2O (Aladdin), 0.012 M Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (Hushi), and varying concentrations of H2PtCl6·xH2O (Aladdin, x = 0, 0.0012, 0.0024, 0.0036, and 0.006 M). Then, solution B, containing 0.12 M Na2CO3 (Lingfeng) and 0.40 M NaOH (Xilong), was prepared. Subsequently, solutions A and B were slowly dripped into a beaker placed in an ice bath and stirred to obtain a suspension, while maintaining the pH at 8.5. The resulting suspension was filtered, and the precipitate was thoroughly washed with deionized water to remove impurities. After drying at 100 °C, the mixed Pt-Co-Al hydroxide precursor was subjected to calcination under static air at 400 °C for 4 h, followed by reduction at 250 °C for 3 h under H2 flow (30 mL/min). The resulting catalysts were named x% Pt-Co-Al, where x represents the Pt content. Notably, some characterization results for the 0 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst have already been presented in our previous publication [21]. Additionally, 5 % Pt/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared using the impregnation method for comparison experiments. This involved slowly adding a 0.03 M H2PtCl6 solution (5 mL) dropwise onto 2 g of nano Al2O3 powder (Aladdin), followed by the same thermal treatment procedure. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The concentrations of Co, Al, and Pt in the catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Varian 720ES instrument. The crystal structures of the samples were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a SmartLab diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. The measurement was performed in a 2θ range of 5–90° and at a scanning rate of 20°/min (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). Crystallite sizes were calculated using the Scherrer equation.[22] N2 physisorption was performed using a Micromeritics 2460 instrument. The samples were degassed at 200 °C before performing N2 adsorption in liquid nitrogen at −196 °C. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore size was calculated by the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method, and the pore volume was calculated using the single point method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer, with binding energies calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of reduced catalysts were captured with an FEI Talos F200S field emission transmission electron microscope at 200 kV to observe the morphology and structure of catalysts. Analyses of H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) were performed using a VDSorb-9Xi chemisorption analyzer. For H2-TPR, the catalysts were first dried under an Ar flow (30 mL/min) at 150 °C for 1 h. The system was then cooled to 70 °C, followed by a temperature increase to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, where it was held for 10 min under a 10 % H₂/Ar mixture with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. In H2-TPD experiments, after an initial reduction in H2 for 3 h, the catalysts were cooled in Ar to 100 °C and maintained at this temperature for 30 min. H2 adsorption occurred at 100 °C for 1 h by exposing the catalyst to a 10 % H₂/Ar mixture. An Ar purge at 30 mL/min for 1 h was then applied before heating the catalysts to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and holding for 50 min to desorb the adsorbed hydrogen. For CO2-TPD, the catalysts were reduced in H2 at 250 °C for 3 h, cooled in Ar to 50 °C, and held for 1 h. A 5 % CO2/He mixture was then introduced at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for CO2 adsorption at 50 °C for 1 h. After a one-hour He flush, the catalysts were heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and maintained for 50 min to desorb the adsorbed CO2. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) is used to measure the changes in the gas stream’s thermal conductivity. The reduction degree (RD, %) of Co and number of active sites (n as, μmol gcat −1) were calculated based on Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. The H2 amount consumed by PtO2 during H2-TPR measurement was calculated according to the ICP-OES results, considering the reduction of all PtO2 to Pt0. (1) RD = n Co , red n Co , tot (2) n as = n H 2 × 2 where n Co,tot (μmol gcat −1) indicates the total moles of Co in the catalyst, and n Co,red (μmol gcat −1) represents the moles of Co that have been reduced. In the quantification of n Co,red and n Co,tot, the low-temperature reduction peaks correspond to the transformation of Co3O4 into metallic Co, with the consumption of 1 mol of H2 yielding ¾ mol of Co0. In contrast, high-temperature peaks are associated with the reduction of CoO and CoAl2O4 to Co0, where 1 mol of H2 produces 1 mol of Co0. Additionally, n as (μmol gcat −1) represents the total number of active sites, including Pt and Co, while n H2 (μmol gcat −1) corresponds to the amount of H2 consumed during H2-TPD. This includes both strongly and weakly adsorbed hydrogen, based on the assumption of dissociative H2 adsorption on the Pt/Co surface [23,24]. 2.3 Catalytic tests CO2 hydrogenation was carried out in accordance with the procedures detailed in our prior study in an autoclave with water as the solvent [9]. Water has been recognized as an efficient solvent for CO2 hydrogenation and is widely used in tank reactors [16,25]. On one hand, the high polarity of water promotes the dissolution of CO2, enhancing the hydrogenation process [26]. On the other hand, water can actively participate in the reaction as a hydrogen source, significantly enhancing the reaction rate and improving selectivity [16]. Although the presence of water can affect the partial pressure [26], it remains an effective solvent for CO2 hydrogenation in tank reactors. Typically, a 50 mL Teflon-lined batch reactor, equipped with a magnetic stirrer, was charged with 50 mg of a pre-reduced catalyst and 15 mL of water. The reactor was subjected to 3 purging cycles using 1 MPa of CO2 to remove residual air. This was followed by the addition of an extra 1 MPa of CO2 and 3 MPa of H2. The reaction mixture was subsequently heated to 180 °C and agitated at a rate of 350 rpm for 1 h. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled in an ice bath, and the gaseous products were collected for offline analysis using an Agilent 8890 GC system, which included a thermal conductivity detector, HayeSep Q, and MolSieve 5 A columns. Methane concentrations were quantified via the external standard method, and their quantities were computed based on the ideal gas law. The liquid products were examined using an Agilent 8860 GC system, which featured a flame ionization detector and an HP-Innowax column, with tetrahydrofuran serving as the internal standard. The yields (Y i, μmol gcat −1 h−1) of methanol, ethanol, propanol, and methane, along with the turnover frequencies (TOF i, h−1), were calculated employing Eqs. 3–5, (3) Y i = n i t × m cat (4) TOF i = Y i n as (5) TOF CO 2 = Y n as , CO 2 Here, Y i (μmol gcat −1 h−1, i denotes methanol, ethanol, propanol, or methane) represents the yield of product i. The term n i (μmol, carbon based) refers to the number of moles of product i. The variable t (h) indicates the reaction time, while m cat (g) denotes the mass of the catalyst used. TOF i (h−1) signifies the turnover frequency (TOF) for product i. TOF CO2 (h−1) denotes the TOF of CO2 conversion, Y represents the yield of all products, and n as,CO2 refers to the number of active sites determined via CO2-TPD analysis. The theoretical CO2 conversion based on the reactor volume can be calculated through Eqs. 6 and 7, (6) n CO 2 , fed = P C O 2 , fed V RT (7) X CO 2 = n CO 2 , converted n CO 2 , fed × 100 % Here, n CO 2 , fed represents the molar amount of CO2 fed into the reactor, P C O 2 , fed denotes the partial pressure of CO2 in the reactor feed, V is the volume of gas in the reactor, and n CO 2 , converted is the molar amount of CO2 converted into products. 2.4 In situ DRIFTS measurements The diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) setup includes a Nicolet IS50 spectrometer equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector. This system is integrated with a Harrick Praying Mantis™ high-temperature reaction chamber for diffuse reflectance. Prior to the DRIFTS analyses the catalysts were reduced ex situ under H2 flow (30 mL/min) at 250 °C for 3 h. After this preparatory step, the catalysts were transferred to the reaction chamber, followed by an Ar purge to ensure a clean environment. The chamber’s temperature was then raised to 180 °C under an Ar atmosphere, and the internal pressure was increased to 4 MPa. To perform the hydrogenation reaction, a mixture of CO2 and H2 gases (12.5/37.5 mL/min) was introduced and the was progressively elevated to 230 °C and then to 280 °C. Throughout the process, DRIFT spectra were recorded in real-time, employing 128 scans at a spectral resolution of 8 cm⁻¹ . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and properties of catalysts ICP-OES was utilized to determine the elemental composition of the x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts post-calcination, with findings detailed in Table 1. The Pt content within these catalysts varies from 0.053 to 0.157 mmol/g, and the molar ratio of Pt to the sum of Co and Al ranges from 0 % to 1.5 %. XRD patterns, illustrated in Figure S1, show the x% Pt-Co-Al samples post-drying, exhibiting an amorphous structure indicative of low crystallinity levels. Moreover, certain diffraction peaks correspond to the characteristic peaks of CoAl-CO3 2⁻, suggesting that the precipitated catalyst predominantly comprises amorphous hydroxides with a partial presence of CoAl-layered double hydroxide (LDH) structures [27]. After calcination at 400 °C, samples with various Pt contents undergo a structural transformation from the original amorphous hydroxides and CoAl-CO3 2− LDH to spinel-structured Co3O4 and/or CoAl2O4/Co2AlO4 [28,29]. The characteristic diffraction peaks appearing at 31.1°, 36.7°, 44.7°, 59.1°, and 65.0° are attributed to the (022), (131), (040), (151), and (044) reflexes of a spinel structure, respectively ( Fig. 1a). Moreover, with increasing Pt content, the crystal size of the Co-Al catalysts increases from 137 Å to 204 Å, while the lattice spacing remained unchanged at 2.44 Å (Table 1). Additionally, no diffraction peaks related to Pt species are observed, indicating that the Pt species are highly or with amorphous structure. N2 physisorption was utilized to assess the textural characteristics of the calcined catalysts (Table S1). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the calcined catalysts, varying in Pt content, are depicted in Figure S2. Each isotherm displays an H3-type hysteresis loop, indicative of the formation of wedge-shaped pores likely due to the assembly of plate-like particles or stratified materials, as referenced in studies [30,31]. Furthermore, the catalysts exhibit a specific surface area ranging from 65 to 79 cm2/g, a pore volume between 0.24 and 0.28 mL/cm2, and pore diameter between 9.0 and 10.5 nm (as determined by the BJH method). These findings imply that the catalysts share comparable textural features. XPS was utilized to examine the oxidation states of the calcined x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. Fig. 1b displays the XPS spectra for the Co 2p orbital, and Table S2 details the deconvolution results. For the 0 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst, the characteristic peaks at 781.30 (2p 1/2) and 796.29 (2p 3/2) eV, along with their satellite peaks, are indicative of Co3+, while the peaks at 782.92 (2p 1/2) and 797.91 (2p 3/2) eV, with their satellites, are indicative of Co2+ [32]. The presence of these peaks and their satellites suggests the existence of low-spin Co3+ in the octahedral sites of Co3O4 and/or CoAl2O4/Co2Al2O4 spinel structures, and high-spin Co2+ in the tetrahedral sites [32]. Notably, the binding energy for Co3+ 2p 3/2 is observed to decrease from 781.30 to 780.31 eV with the introduction of Pt into the Co-Al catalyst, which is indicative of electron transfer due to strong interactions between Pt species and the spinel structures [33]. Additionally, an increase in Pt content leads to a rise in binding energy from 780.31 to 780.51 eV. This may be related to the electron transfer effect of Pt or the redistribution of surface species [34]. Moreover, the increasing Pt concentration leads to a decreasing Co3+/(Co2+ + Co3+) ratio from 43 % to 35 %. This may be ascribed to the entry of Pt into the spinel lattice, leading to a variation in the surface valence of the Co species [35]. Fig. 1c shows the XPS spectra of the Pt 4d orbital for the calcined Pt-containing catalysts. Two distinct peaks are observed at binding energies of 318.6 eV (Pt 4d3/2) and 335.3 eV (Pt 4d5/2),confirming the presence of PtO2 species on the surface of the calcined catalyst samples [36]. The influence of Pt on the reducibility of Co-Al catalysts was investigated using H2-TPR, as depicted in Fig. 2a. TPR profiles for all samples exhibit two distinct reduction peaks, the low-temperature α peaks and the high temperature β peaks. The low temperature peaks can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (Eq. 4) and the subsequent reduction of CoO to Co0 (Eq. 5) [37], as well as the reduction of small amounts of Pt oxides and Pt-O-Co bonds. While the high temperature β peak arises from the reduction of Co-Al spinel structure/strongly interacted Co-Al species to Co0 (Eqs. 6 and 7) [37]. (5) Co3O4 + H2 → 3 CoO + H2O (6) CoO + H2 → Co0 + H2O (7) CoAl2O4 + H2 → Co0 + 4 Al2O3 + H2O It can be observed from the profiles that both reduction peaks noticeably shift towards lower temperatures upon the addition of Pt. This indicates that the presence of Pt triggers hydrogen spillover, where H atoms adsorbed on Pt surfaces spill onto the Co oxide species’ surfaces, facilitating easier reduction of the catalyst, consistent with prior reports [33,38]. The α peak temperature follows the sequence 0 % Pt-Co-Al > 0.5 % Pt-Co-Al > 0.7 % Pt-Co-Al > 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al, with the 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al sample experiencing the greatest impact on the reducibility. Its α peak temperature decreases by 131 °C, indicating the strongest hydrogen spillover effect occurring on its surface, making it the most easily reducible. Table S3 presents the reduction degrees of each sample calculated based on the TPR results and Eq. 1. It is observed that the reduction degree of the Co-Al catalyst without Pt promoter is only 5.88 % at 250 °C. However, the presence of 0.5 % Pt in the Pt-Co-Al catalyst promotes the hydrogen spillover effect, leading to a decrease in reduction temperature [15] and an increase in the reduction degree to 26.07 %. When the Pt content reaches 0.7 %, the reduction degree increases by 5.72 %, and further addition of Pt results in only a slight increase in the reduction degree. These results indicate that an appropriate Pt content helps to promote the hydrogen spillover effect, thereby enhancing the reduction degree of the Co-Al catalyst. Moreover, Figure S3 presents the XRD patterns of the x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts reduced at 250 °C. It is observed that the catalyst without Pt mainly exhibits diffraction indexes of CoO due to the partial reduction of Co3O4/CoAl2O4/Co2AlO4 [39]. However, with the introduction of Pt promoter, diffraction indexes related to Co0 emerge, and as the Pt content increases, the intensity of CoO peak gradually decreases while that of Co0 increases. This is found to be consistent with the increasing reduction degree as suggested by H2-TPR. The morphology and structure of the reduced 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst was studied using TEM ( Fig. 3). The 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst exhibits a stacked spherical morphology. High-resolution TEM image (Fig. 3d) shows d-spacings of 2.01 Å and 1.98 Å, aligning with the (002) facet of hexagonal close-packed (hcp) Co0 [40] and the (111) facet of face-centered cubic (fcc) Co0 [41], respectively, consistent with the existence of Co0 detected by XRD. Another d-spacing of 2.28 Å is ascribed to the (111) facet of Pt0 NPs [42]. TEM and XRD analyses show no evidence of Co-Pt alloy formation, suggesting that Pt is more likely present as Pt⁰ nanoparticles rather than as a Pt-Co alloy. H2-TPD was conducted over x% Pt-Co-Al to investigate the effects of catalysts’ ability to activate H2. Fig. 2b shows the H2-TPD profiles, and Table S4 summarizes the H2 uptake of various catalysts. It is evident that the catalysts exhibit low temperature (α) and high temperature (β) desorption peaks at 165 and 340 °C, corresponding to weak and strong chemisorption of H, respectively [43]. Upon Pt promotion, the H2 uptake increase first but decreases with further increasing Pt content. The highest H2 uptake over 0.5 % Pt-Co-Al may be related to its optimized reduction degree (as evidenced by TPR), providing abundant metal/oxide interfaces for H2 activation [9]. Notably, with increasing Pt loading, the fraction of the weakly-adsorbed hydrogen (hydrogen desorbed below 250 °C) increases from 17.9 % to 28.3 %, suggesting enhanced hydrogen spillover with Pt promotion [44]. CO2-TPD was employed to investigate the activation of CO2 on the catalysts’ surface (Fig. 2c, Table S5). The peaks observed at lower temperatures (100–200 °C) are attributed to weakly chemisorbed CO2, while the higher temperature ones (300–400 °C) are ascribed to strongly chemisorbed CO2. The increase in CO2 uptake upon the addition of Pt may be due to Pt enhancing the reducibility of the Co-Al catalyst, leading to an increase in the concentration of surface oxygen vacancies and thereby significantly enhancing the catalyst’s ability to adsorb CO2 [45,46]. The 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al sample exhibits the highest amount of CO2 adsorption in CO2-TPD experiments, reaching 1004.8 μmolCO2 gcat −1. According to the findings of Guo et al., surface strong basic sites in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction can weaken the adsorption of hydrogen, enhance hydrogen spillover performance, and thereby promote CO2 activation [47]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The reduced catalysts were evaluated for CO2 hydrogenation in water in an autoclave. Fig. 4 illustrates the yields of methane, methanol, ethanol, and propanol over Pt-Co-Al catalysts, as well as the 5 % Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. The catalyst without Pt promotion (0 % Pt-Co-Al), yields 1518.3 μmol gcat −1 h−1 methane and trace amounts of alcohols. Upon the introduction of Pt, the yields for methane, methanol, ethanol, and propanol increase. 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al reaches the highest activity, with methane yield of 46615.4 μmol gcat −1 h−1 and alcohols yield of reaching 730.0 μmol gcat −1 h−1 (with C2+OH accounting for 30.2 %). Notably, the 3 % Pt/Al2O3 catalyst possesses a low activity producing mainly methane with a yield of 1631.3 μmol gcat −1 h−1. This suggests that Pt alone is not effective for CO2 hydrogenation but rather acts as a promoter enhancing Co-Al catalysts’ activity. Accordingly, CO2 conversion increases with higher Pt loading, as follows: 0.3 %, 4.8 %, 9.7 %, and 10.1 % for 0 % Pt-Co-Al, 0.5 % Pt-Co-Al, 0.7 % Pt-Co-Al, and 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al, respectively. CO was not detected for this series of catalysts (Figure S4). The absence of CO product is likely due to the strong hydrogenation activity of these catalysts, which converts the CO intermediate into methane. Time dependency of CO2 hydrogenation over the 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst was investigated at 0.5 h, 1 h, and 3 h (Figure S5). No significant change in product yield was observed as the reaction time increased from 0.5 to 1 h. However, a notable decrease in product yield was observed at 3 h, likely due to inefficient mass transfer caused by reactant depletion. A reaction duration of 1 h allows us to evaluate the catalyst’s performance within the kinetic control range. The activation energies were determined by conducting CO2 hydrogenation at various temperatures and deriving the values from Arrhenius plots (Figure S6) [48]. The apparent activation energies for CO2 hydrogenation over the 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al and 0 % Pt-Co-Al catalysts are 146.8 kJ/mol and 184.0 kJ/mol, respectively. This demonstrates that the addition of Pt effectively reduces the apparent activation energy for CO2 hydrogenation, aligning with the high activity observed for the 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst. Moreover, a strong linear correlation is observed among the yields of methane, methanol, and ethanol ( Fig. 5), indicating that the formation of these products may share a common intermediate [11]. It is noteworthy that the catalysts with higher Pt concentration (0.7 % and 1.5 %) show an enhancement for the formation of higher alcohols suggesting that the increase of Pt content is conducive to C-C coupling. In addition, we compare the performance of the Pt-Co-Al catalyst with state-of-the-art Co-based catalysts under similar reaction conditions (Table S6). The 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst achieves a CO2 conversion rate of 47.3 mmol gcat −1 h−1, surpassing the state-of-the-art Co-based catalysts. This highlights the positive effects of Pt promotion. The XPS analysis of the 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst after CO2 hydrogenation (Figure S7) reveals that Pt remains in its reduced Pt0 state, while Co is present in oxidation states of 2 + and 3 + . This oxidation of Co is likely due to air exposure during sample collection post-reaction, as Co0 is highly susceptible to oxidation in air due to its reactive nature [49]. However, under the reaction conditions, which involve an abundant supply of H2, such oxidation is unlikely to occur. The number of active sites was estimated using Eq. 2 presupposing dissociative adsorption of H2, and the TOFs were calculated based on Eq. 4. Fig. 6 presents the TOFs for CO2 conversion and the formation of various products over various x% Pt-Co-Al catalysts. It can be observed that the TOFs increase first and then flatten with increasing Pt concentration. The highest TOFs for methane (77.2 h−1), methanol (0.84 h−1), and higher alcohols (0.39 h−1) formation are reached by the catalyst with the highest Pt concentration. 3.3 The enhancement mechanism of Pt promoter The interaction between H and the catalyst surface is crucial for CO2 hydrogenation because H not only serves as a reactant but also plays a key role in activating and dissociating CO2 [50,51]. The hydrogen spillover effect has been recognized as one of the key factors influencing CO2 hydrogenation [52,53]. It has been previously found that Pt promoter can enhance hydrogen spillover, weakening the adsorption of H on the catalysts’ surface. We further investigated the relationship between the fraction of weakly adsorbed H (fraction of the H desorbed below 250 °C) and the TOFs for CO2 conversion and the production of various products ( Fig. 7). The TOFs first increase with an increasing fraction of weakly adsorbed H and then flatten. As the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation is conducted at 180 °C, the strongly bound H cannot desorb at this temperature, being less important for the reaction [54,55]. Thus, increasing the fraction of the weakly bounded H promotes CO2 hydrogenation. Interestingly, we further found that the fraction of weakly adsorbed CO2 increases with increasing fraction of weakly adsorbed H ( Fig. 8), this also partially contributes to the enhanced CO2 hydrogenation performance [56]. In situ DRIFTS was employed to study the reaction intermediates over 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst during the CO2 hydrogenation ( Fig. 9a and c). The absorption bands associated with gas phase CO2 (2260–2380 cm−1) [57] and adsorbed CO2 (3596, 3729, 3700 cm−1) [58–60] can be observed. As the reaction temperature increases from 180 °C to 230 °C, various C1 intermediates emerge: *CO (2077, 1750 cm−1) [61,62], *HCOO (2822, 1868, 1698 cm−1) [63–65], *CH3 (1342 cm−1) [66], and peaks corresponding to methane (3014, 1303 cm−1) [67,68]. Upon further increasing the reaction temperature to 280 °C, *CH3O (1734, 1457, 1435, 1056 cm−1) [69–72], and *CH3CH2O (1473, 1419 cm−1) [73,74] appear. Based on previous studies, *HCOO is considered a crucial intermediate for alcohol and methane formation [9]. It can be converted to *CH3O during the reaction, which is then hydrogenated to methanol. *HCOO can also form *CHx, which can directly hydrogenate to produce methane or couple with *HCOO or *CO to form ethoxy species, ultimately leading to ethanol formation. In situ DRIFTS analysis of the Pt-free 0 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst (Fig. 9b and c) reveals that, compared to 1.5 % Pt-Co-Al, the intensity of bands associated with methane, *HCOO, *CO, *CH3O, and *CH3CH2O decreases, whereas the carbonate-related bands (1610, 1362, 1293 cm−1) [75–77] are notably stronger. This suggests that the limited reactive H species on the surface of the 0 % Pt-Co-Al catalyst hinders the conversion of carbonate species into formate intermediates, thereby suppressing subsequent hydrogenation reactions and resulting in reduced catalytic activity [78]. Notably, the in situ DRIFTS measurements were conducted in the gas phase, unlike the aqueous phase used for catalyst evaluation. This difference may potentially result in a distinct reaction pathway. Based on the characterization results, the enhancement for CO2 hydrogenation caused by Pt as a promoter can be illustrated ( Fig. 10). The hydrogen spillover from Pt on the one hand promotes the reduction of Co. This in turn leads to an optimized amount of Co0 and Co2+ in the catalyst, and provides more active sites as evidenced by H2-TPD [9]. On the other hand, the hydrogen spillover from Pt weakens the adsorption of H, meanwhile reducing the adsorption strength of CO2 [79,80]. This results in moderate adsorption of H/CO2 and facilitates the formation of *HCOO, *CH3, and *CO intermediates and the coupling between *HCOO/*CO and *CH3, enhancing the formation of ethanol. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation method and employed for CO2 hydrogenation reaction, yielding mainly methane, methanol, and higher alcohols. Co-Al catalysts containing 1.5 % Pt exhibits the best performance, with a yield of 47.3 mmol gcat −1 h−1, wherein alcohol products constituted 1.5 % (729.9 μmol gcat −1 h−1) of the total products, and higher alcohols accounted for 31.3 % (220.6 μmol gcat −1 h−1) of the total alcohol products. The Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts trigger the hydrogen spillover, optimizing the catalysts’ reducibility, exposing more active sites. Moreover, the adsorption of H is weakened by Pt promoter induced hydrogen spillover, facilitating the formation of *HCOO, *CH3, and *CO intermediates and the coupling between *HCOO/*CO and *CH3 and enhancing the formation of higher alcohols. coredata.dc:description: CO2 hydrogenation presents a crucial pathway for carbon circularity. The activation, adsorption, and hydrogen spillover are key processes in CO2 hydrogenation. This study investigates the effects of hydrogen spillover induced by Pt on CO2 hydrogenation over Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts. A series of Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts were synthesized via co-precipitation and employed for CO2 hydrogenation. The optimized Pt-promoted Co-Al catalyst efficiently converts CO2, leading to the formation of methane (46.6 mmol gcat −1 h−1), methanol (509.4 μmol gcat −1 h−1), and higher alcohols (220.6 μmol gcat −1 h−1). The Pt-promoted Co-Al catalysts facilitate hydrogen spillover, optimizing the catalysts’ reducibility and exposing more active sites. Moreover, the hydrogen adsorption is weakened due to the Pt induced hydrogen spillover, which facilitates the formation of *HCOO, *CH3, and *CO intermediates. This in turn facilitate the coupling between *HCOO/*CO and *CH3, enhancing the formation of higher alcohols.
